A general increase in unemployment in the coal mining industry took place during the quarter. In some areas the increase took the form of extended short-time working, whilst in others, for example, South "Wales, the' increase was mainly in whole-time unemployment. For the country as a whole there was atotal increase in unemployment of just over 90,000 for the three months endedJune.IRON, STEEL AND TIN PLATE. While the production of steel showed a slight decrease during the quarterthere was, on the whole, little change in the employment position of the trade.In pig-iron manufacture, however, a number of blast furnaces were damped down,employment as a result becoming somewhat slacker. In the tin-plate trade, on theother hand, employment was considerably better at the end, than at the beginningof the quarter.SHIPBUILDING AND SHIP-REPAIRING. The completion of a large number of contracts and the scarcity of replace-ment orders were responsible for a general slackening in activity in the ship-building industry during the quarter. Ship-repair work was also somewhatslacker, although in Southampton there was some improvement.ENGINEERING. Employment in the engineering industry remained on the whole fairly steadyduring the quarter. There was, however, some falling off in the marine engineering section, whilst the usual seasonal slackness in motor engineering also made itself apparent.TEXTILES. Cotton. In the manufacturing section of the cotton industry, and inparticular in the American spinning section, a general increase in short-time working took place during the quarter. Employment in the Egyptian sectionremained fairly good. Woollen and Y/orsted. An extension of short-time working was reported from the chief sections of the woollen and worsted trade, the total percentage ofunemployment in the industry rising to 12"0 at the end of June. Other Textiles. In the silk and hosiery trades employment remained fairlysteady during the quarter, but a slight decline in activity in the lace, linen andjute trades took place.BUILDING. BRICK AND TILE MANUFACTURE. During April and May some seasonal improvement took place in the buildingindustry, but this was counteracted by a decline in employment during June, due mainly to a falling off in the decorating section of the trade. In the brick andtile industry a slight improvement was shown during the period. CLOTHING TRADES. In the clothing and tailoring trades the normal seasonal slackness appears tohave set in somewhat earlier than usual, with the result that employment wasconsiderably slacker in June than in the two previous months. Similarly in theboot and shoe trade unemployment more than doubled itself during the quarter.TRANSPORT, DOCK LABOUR AND SHIPPING SERVICES. Employment at the docks continued to remain slack. WORK INSTITUTED FOR RELIEF OF UNEMPLOYMENT. Numbers Employed. [See note on page 1 of November 1924 Report (CP. 541 (24)).] The table which follows has been prepared to show, so far as information is available, the number of men employed on works instituted, with financial assistance from the Exchequer or the Road Fund, for the relief of unemployment. Scope of Table. The schemes included are those undertaken by Local and other Authorities and Public Companies with a financial contribution from the State with the object of relieving unemployment; and works in respect of which guarantees have been given under the Trade Facilities Acts as capital undertakings calculated to promote employment in this country. Schemes to which State financial assistance is given, but which are not undertaken primarily for the relief of unemployment (e.g., Housing Schemes), and works put in hand by Local Authorities without State assistance are not included. Certain other schemes involving Government assistance are also excluded in view of the impracticability of ascertaining the exact number of men who are directly provided with employment thereby; these include the Export Credits Scbeme and contracts for equipment, clothing, &c, accelerated by Government Contracting Departments. Method of Compilation. :The figures for the Road and Bridge Schemes assisted by the Ministry of Transport and for schemes assisted by the Unemployment Grants Committee are (with the exception of certain road schemes in respect of which returns are received direct by the Ministry of Transport) obtained from returns received at Employment Exchanges from local and other Authorities and Public Companies. (Dominions Office.) Under the Empire Settlement Act, 1922 (an Act to make better provision for furthering British settlement in His Majesty's OverseaDominions), various schemes have been agreed with Dominion Authorities. This Act, as its title implies, is not one of the government measures designed to deal with unemployment, and should not be so regarded. For many years before and after the war, the natural increase of population exceeded the net migration movement by about 300,000 ayear, but recently the gap between the natural increase and the net migration movement has tended to diminish. During 1926, the natural increase in England, Scotland and Wales was 279,775, and the net migration movement was 103,969. Unemployment Insurance. (Estimates, Class V, Vote 9.) The National Insurance Act of 1911 provided insurance against unemploymentin certain selected industries. It was followed by the Act of 1916, which increased the numbers of persons insured, and, in 1920, by an Act of general scope which applied compulsory insurance against unemployment to 12,000,000 persons.Subsequent amending Acts modified the conditions of receipt of benefit, increased contributions, provided benefit in respect of dependants, and authorised theTreasury to make advances out of the Consolidated Fund up to a limit of 30,000,000. By the Unemployment Insurance Act, 1927, the rates of benefit were revisedfrom the 19th April, 1928, as follows : 17s. (instead of 18s.) a week for men, 15s. aweek for women, with 7s. (instead of 5s.) a week for an adult dependant and 2s. aweek for each young dependent child. As from July, 1928, reduced rates of benefitoperated for persons under 21 years of age having no dependants ; contributions alsowere reduced for all persons under 21 years of age. Benefit may be paid for threemonths to a claimant who has paid 30 contributions in the two years preceding the date of his claim, and may continue throughout each subsequent period ofthree months at the beginning of which this condition is still satisfied. During a transitional period, which in individual cases may extend to April 1930, benefitmay be paid to a claimant who does not satisfy the above condition, if he has paid 8 contributions in the two preceding years or 30 contributions at any timeand fulfils certain other conditions. (C) MINISTRY OF TRANSPORT SCHEMES. ROAD AND BRIDGE PROGRAMME, 1919-20. To assist in the provision of employment for demobilised members of HisMajesty's Forces until such time as they could be re-absorbed into industry, theGovernment after the Armistice inaugurated a special fund for the purpose ofmaking grants on certain conditions to Highway Authorities for road work. Thetotal of such grants has amounted to approximately 9,328,000 for Great Britainand it is estimated that the works carried out by Local Authorities in order to earn agrant aggregated in cost to approximately 20,000,000. In England and Wales the provision of small holdings under the Land Settle-ment (Facilities) Act, 1919, and other Land Settlement Schemes for the benefitprimarily of ex-Service men, are carried out (a) through the agency of CountyCouncils and Councils of County Boroughs and (&) through the Ministry ofAgriculture and Fisheries. Settlement through Local Authorities. The net capital cost of these schemes upto the 31st March, 1926, when the Land Settlement Scheme came to an end, isestimated to be 15,250,000, of which approximately 14,050,000 (net) was loanedby the Public Works Loan Board. Interest in respect of such loans is payable byCouncils. Under Section 26 of the Land Settlement (Facilities) Act, 1919, theExchequer bore the loss incurred up to the 31st March, 1926, on the Councils' SmallHoldings account (e.g., due to charging a fair as opposed to an economic rent), sofar as such loss had been reasonably and necessarily incurred. As from the 1st April, 1926, the Exchequer assistance takes the form of annualcontributions to meet the difference between the loan charges and the estimated net income from the Councils' estates. These contributions which did not commenceuntil the year 1927, will vary from year to year, and their total capitalized valuecannot at present be estimated. In Scotland land settlement is not conducted through the agency of CountyCouncils. Ministry''s Settlements. After the Armistice, Juvenile Unemployment Centres were opened in certainlocalities to deal with the problem of unemployed juveniles. After a period of closure centres were again established, and the cost, which was originally shared bythe Board of Education and Local Authorities, was, from the 1st April, 1923, to the31st March, 1924, partly met out of Relief of Unemployment Vote by grants up to75 per cent, in respect of approved schemes, the - Local Authority providing theremaining 25 per cent. From the 1st April, 1924, the Exchequer Grant was, as anemergency measure, for so long as unemployment amongst juveniles remains acute,raised to 100 per cent, of the approved out-of-pocket expenses of Local EducationAuthorities. From the 1st April, 1926, the Exchequer Grant was revised as follows: (1.) To Authorities in whose areas the average rate of unemployment among insured juveniles exceeded 6 per cent, during the twelve months which ended on the 23rd November, 1925. A per capita grant fixed by the Minister for each Authority separately equalto the approved average weekly cost to the Authority of each Juvenile in averageattendance, taking into account recurrent expenditure only, during the twelvemonths which ended on the 30th June, 30th September, or 31st December, 1925,whichever was the latest period for which consecutive claims had been received. Ifcomplete figures for one year ending on one of the above dates were not available,or if the Authority had not previously opened Centres, the per capita grant was fixed by the Minister on such information, including the Authority's proposals for1926, as was available to him.(2.) To Authorities in whose areas the average rate of unemployment among insured juveniles was not less than 3 per cent, and not more than 6 per cent, during the twelve months which ended on the 23rd November, 1925. Either (i) a per capita grant calculated as in (1) above, but equal to three-quarters only of the approved average weekly cost, or (ii) a grant of 75 per cent.of the approved out-of-pocket expenditure incurred by the Authority during thefinancial year 1926, as the Authority chose. ySCHEMES FOR TRAINING WOMEN AND JUVENILES AND YOUNG UNEMPLOYED FIT MEN.
